vaccine_function.formula: Vaccines contain antigens that stimulate immunity without causing disease, producing memory cells
vaccine_function.correct: Vaccines trigger primary immune responses and memory cell formation for rapid secondary responses

wrong.answer: Vaccines inject antibodies into the body
wrong.fix: Vaccines contain antigens that stimulate your immune system to make antibodies
wrong.action: Vaccines = antigens → active immunity; Antisera = antibodies → passive immunity

wrong.answer: Vaccines cause the disease they prevent
wrong.fix: Vaccines use weakened, killed, or partial pathogens that cannot cause disease
wrong.action: Vaccines: attenuated/inactivated/subunit = cannot cause disease

wrong.answer: Vaccines provide immediate protection
wrong.fix: Vaccines take time (weeks) as the immune system responds and forms memory
wrong.action: Vaccines = delayed but lasting; Antisera = immediate but temporary

persistent.action: Vaccine: antigen → immune response → memory cells → lasting protection

vaccine_components.formula: Vaccines contain antigens (weakened/killed/subunit) often with adjuvants to enhance immune response
vaccine_components.correct: Antigenic determinants may be conjugated to adjuvants that boost immunogenicity

wrong.answer: All vaccines contain live pathogens
wrong.fix: Only live attenuated vaccines contain replicating organisms; others use killed or partial pathogens
wrong.action: Types: live attenuated, inactivated, subunit, toxoid, mRNA

wrong.answer: Adjuvants are antigens
wrong.fix: Adjuvants enhance immune responses; antigens are the targets of immunity
wrong.action: Antigen = target; Adjuvant = immune booster

wrong.answer: Adjuvants are harmful additives
wrong.fix: Adjuvants safely enhance vaccine effectiveness by stimulating innate immunity
wrong.action: Adjuvants: aluminium salts, lipids, etc. = safe, effective boosters

persistent.action: Vaccine components: antigen (target) + adjuvant (booster) + preservatives + stabilisers

primary_response.formula: Vaccination triggers a primary immune response with antibody production and memory cell formation
primary_response.correct: The primary response is slower and weaker but establishes memory for future protection

wrong.answer: Primary response provides immediate protection
wrong.fix: Primary response takes 1-2 weeks to develop; protection is delayed
wrong.action: Primary: slow (1-2 weeks), establishes memory

wrong.answer: Primary response produces memory cells only
wrong.fix: Primary response produces both effector cells (immediate) and memory cells (future)
wrong.action: Primary response → effector cells + memory cells

wrong.answer: One vaccination always provides lifelong immunity
wrong.fix: Some vaccines require boosters as immunity wanes over time
wrong.action: Immunity duration varies; boosters may be needed

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of primary immune response
persistent.action: Primary response: antigen → B/T cell activation → antibodies + memory cells

secondary_response.formula: Upon pathogen exposure, memory cells trigger rapid, strong secondary responses preventing disease
secondary_response.correct: Secondary responses are faster, stronger, and longer-lasting than primary responses

wrong.answer: Secondary responses are the same as primary
wrong.fix: Secondary responses are faster (days vs weeks) and produce more antibodies
wrong.action: Secondary > Primary: faster, stronger, longer

wrong.answer: Secondary response requires another vaccination
wrong.fix: Secondary response occurs when vaccinated person encounters the actual pathogen
wrong.action: Vaccination → pathogen exposure → secondary response → protection

wrong.answer: Memory cells respond slowly
wrong.fix: Memory cells respond rapidly because they have lower activation thresholds
wrong.action: Memory cells: pre-primed, low threshold, rapid response

persistent.action: Secondary response: memory cells → rapid activation → faster, stronger protection

herd_immunity.formula: Herd immunity protects unvaccinated individuals when sufficient population immunity reduces transmission
herd_immunity.correct: High vaccination rates create protective barriers for vulnerable populations who cannot be vaccinated

wrong.answer: Herd immunity only protects vaccinated individuals
wrong.error: Missing the point of herd immunity
wrong.fix: Herd immunity specifically protects unvaccinated individuals through reduced transmission
wrong.action: Vaccinated protect unvaccinated by reducing pathogen circulation

wrong.answer: Herd immunity requires 100% vaccination
wrong.fix: Herd immunity threshold varies by disease, typically 80-95%
wrong.action: Threshold depends on disease transmissibility (R0)

wrong.answer: Individual vaccination doesn't contribute to herd immunity
wrong.fix: Each vaccinated individual contributes to community protection
wrong.action: Individual vaccination → community benefit

persistent.action: Herd immunity: high vaccination → reduced transmission → vulnerable protected

threshold_factors.formula: Herd immunity threshold depends on pathogen transmissibility, population density, and social behaviour
threshold_factors.correct: More transmissible diseases require higher vaccination rates to achieve herd immunity

wrong.answer: All diseases have the same herd immunity threshold
wrong.fix: Threshold varies: measles ~95%, polio ~80%, flu ~70%
wrong.action: Higher R0 = higher threshold needed

wrong.answer: Population behaviour doesn't affect threshold
wrong.fix: Contact patterns and social behaviour affect transmission and threshold
wrong.action: More contacts = higher transmission = higher threshold

wrong.answer: Herd immunity is permanent once achieved
wrong.fix: Herd immunity requires ongoing high vaccination rates to be maintained
wrong.action: Falling vaccination rates → lost herd immunity → outbreaks

persistent.action: Threshold factors: transmissibility (R0), density, behaviour, vaccine effectiveness

booster_doses.formula: Booster doses reinforce immunity by restimulating memory cells when protection wanes
booster_doses.correct: Boosters trigger secondary responses in previously vaccinated individuals, increasing memory cell numbers

wrong.answer: Boosters are primary vaccinations
wrong.fix: Boosters stimulate existing memory; primary doses establish initial immunity
wrong.action: Primary = first exposure; Booster = restimulation of memory

wrong.answer: Boosters are unnecessary if initially vaccinated
wrong.fix: Memory cells may decline; boosters restore and strengthen immunity
wrong.action: Boosters needed when immunity wanes below protective levels

wrong.answer: Boosters work exactly like the first dose
wrong.fix: Boosters trigger faster, stronger secondary responses due to existing memory
wrong.action: Boosters → secondary response → enhanced protection

persistent.action: Boosters: reinforce waning immunity, stimulate memory cells, enhance protection

eradication.formula: Disease eradication through vaccination requires eliminating pathogen circulation globally
eradication.correct: Smallpox was eradicated through vaccination due to favourable disease characteristics and global cooperation

wrong.answer: Any disease can be easily eradicated
wrong.fix: Eradication requires specific conditions: no animal reservoir, stable pathogen, identifiable symptoms
wrong.action: Eradication criteria: human-only host, stable, visible, effective vaccine

wrong.answer: Eradication and elimination are identical
wrong.fix: Elimination = disease removed from a region; Eradication = disease removed globally
wrong.action: Elimination = local; Eradication = global

wrong.answer: Vaccination alone achieved smallpox eradication
wrong.fix: Eradication required vaccination plus surveillance, ring vaccination, and global coordination
wrong.action: Eradication = vaccination + surveillance + coordination + disease features

persistent.action: Smallpox eradication: visible symptoms, no reservoir, stable virus, global effort
